Welcome to Contact_app’s documentation!¶

REST API main¶

async main.custom_midleware(request: Request, call_next) → Response¶

The custom_midleware function is a custom middleware function that adds the time it took to process the request to the response headers. It does this by getting the current time before calling call_next, and then subtracting the start_time from it after call_next returns. The result is added to a new header called &quot;performance&quot;.

Parameters:

  • request – Request: Pass the request to the next middleware

  • call_next – Call the next middleware in the chain

Returns:

A response object with a performance header

async main.healthchecker(db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db)) → dict¶

The healthchecker function is a simple function that checks the database connection. It returns a JSON response with the message &quot;Welcome to FastAPI!&quot; if everything is working correctly.

Parameters:

db – Session: Pass the database connection to the function

Returns:

A dictionary with a message

async main.limit_access_by_ip(request: Request, call_next: Callable) → JSONResponse¶

The limit_access_by_ip function is a middleware function that limits access to the API by IP address. It checks if the client’s IP address is in a list of allowed addresses, and if not, it returns an error message.

Parameters:

  • request – Request: Get the client ip address

  • call_next – Callable: Call the next function in the middleware chain

Returns:

A jsonresponse object with a 403 status code and an error message

async main.on_startup() → None¶

The on_startup function is called when the application starts. It prints a message to the console, so that you know where to go in your browser.

Returns:

None

async main.startup() → FastAPILimiter¶

The startup function is called when the server starts up. It’s a good place to initialize things that are needed by your application, such as databases and caches. It can also be used to pre-load data into memory, or do other tasks that need to happen before the server begins serving requests.

Returns:

A fastapilimiter object

REST API repository Addressbook¶

async src.repository.addressbook.add_email_to_contact(db: AsyncSession, email_create: EmailCreate, current_user: int, contact_id: int) → Contact¶

The add_email_to_contact function adds an email to a contact.

Parameters:

  • db – AsyncSession: Connect to the database

  • email_create – EmailCreate: Create a new email for the contact

  • current_user – int: Ensure that the user is only able to add an email address to a contact

  • contact_id – int: Identify the contact to add the email to

Returns:

A contact object

async src.repository.addressbook.add_phone_to_contact(db: AsyncSession, phone_create: PhoneCreate, current_user: int, contact_id: int) → Contact | None¶

The add_phone_to_contact function adds a phone number to an existing contact.

Parameters:

  • db – AsyncSession: Connect to the database

  • phone_create – PhoneCreate: Create a new phone number for the contact

  • current_user – int: Get the current user id

  • contact_id – int: Identify the contact that we want to add a phone number to

Returns:

A contact object, which is a row in the database

async src.repository.addressbook.create_contact(db: AsyncSession, contact_create: AddressbookCreate, email_create: EmailCreate, phone_create: PhoneCreate, current_user: int) → AddressBookContact¶

The create_contact function creates a new contact in the address book.

Parameters:

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass the database session to the function

  • contact_create – AddressbookCreate: Create a new contact

  • email_create – EmailCreate: Create a new email object

  • phone_create – PhoneCreate: Create a new phone number for the contact

  • current_user – int: Get the current user’s id

Returns:

A contact object

async src.repository.addressbook.get_contact(db: AsyncSession, contact_id: int, current_user: int) → AddressBookContact | None¶

The get_contact function is used to retrieve a single contact from the address book.

Parameters:

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass the database session to the function

  • contact_id – int: Identify the contact to be retrieved

  • current_user – int: Ensure that the user is only able to access their own contacts

Returns:

A contact from the database

async src.repository.addressbook.get_contacts(skip: int, limit: int, current_user: int, db: AsyncSession)¶
The get_contacts function returns a list of contacts from the address book.

The function takes in three parameters: skip, limit, and current_user. Skip is an integer that determines how many contacts to skip over before returning results. Limit is an integer that determines how many results to return after skipping over the specified number of contacts. Current_user is an integer representing the user whose address book we are querying.

Parameters:

  • skip – int: Skip the first n records

  • limit – int: Limit the number of results returned

  • current_user – int: Filter the results to only return contacts that belong to the current user

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

A list of contacts

async src.repository.addressbook.read_contact_days_to_birthday(db: AsyncSession, days_to_birthday: int, current_user: int)¶

The read_contact_days_to_birthday function returns a list of contacts that have birthdays within the next X days.

Parameters:

  • db – AsyncSession: Connect to the database

  • days_to_birthday – int: Specify the number of days to look ahead for upcoming birthdays

  • current_user – int: Filter the results to only show contacts that belong to the current user

Returns:

A list of contacts that have a birthday within the next x days

async src.repository.addressbook.remove_contact(db: AsyncSession, current_user: int, contact_id: int) → AddressBookContact | None¶

The remove_contact function removes a contact from the database.

Parameters:

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass in the database session

  • current_user – int: Ensure that the user is only able to delete their own contacts

  • contact_id – int: Identify the contact to be deleted

Returns:

The contact that was removed

async src.repository.addressbook.search_contacts(criteria: str, current_user: int, db: AsyncSession)¶

The search_contacts function takes in a string of criteria and the current user’s id, and returns all contacts that match the search criteria. The search is case-insensitive.

Parameters:

  • criteria – str: Search for the user’s contacts

  • current_user – int: Filter the results to only return contacts that belong to the current user

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

A list of contacts

async src.repository.addressbook.update_contact_birthday(db: AsyncSession, body: AddressbookUpdateBirthday, current_user: int, contact_id: int) → AddressBookContact¶

The update_contact_birthday function updates the birthday of a contact.

Parameters:

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass the database session to this function

  • body – AddressbookUpdateBirthday: Get the new birthday from the request body

  • current_user – int: Ensure that the user is only able to update their own contacts

  • contact_id – int: Identify the contact that is being updated

Returns:

The updated contact

async src.repository.addressbook.update_contact_name(db: AsyncSession, body: AddressbookUpdateName, current_user: int, contact_id: int)¶

The update_contact_name function updates the first and last name of a contact.

Parameters:

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass in the database session

  • body – AddressbookUpdateName: Pass the new first and last name to the function

  • current_user – int: Ensure that the user is only able to update their own contacts

  • contact_id – int: Specify the id of the contact that will be updated

Returns:

A contact object

REST API repository Users¶

async src.repository.users.change_password(user: User, password: str, db: AsyncSession) → User¶

The change_password function takes in a user, body, and db. The function then sets the password of the user to be equal to the confirm_password field of body. It then adds this new information into our database and commits it. Finally, we refresh our database with this new information.

Parameters:

  • user – User: Get the user object from the database

  • body – ResetPassword: Get the new password from the request body

  • db – AsyncSession: Access the database

Returns:

The user object with the new password

async src.repository.users.confirmed_email(email: str, db: AsyncSession) → None¶

The confirmed_email function takes an email address and a database session as arguments. It then queries the database for a user with that email address, and sets their confirmed field to True. Finally, it commits the change to the database.

Parameters:

  • email – str: Specify the email address of the user to be confirmed

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass in the database session

Returns:

None

async src.repository.users.create_user(body: UserModel, db: AsyncSession) → User¶

The create_user function takes a UserModel object and a database session as arguments. It then creates an instance of the Gravatar class, passing in the user’s email address. The get_image() method is called on this instance to retrieve the user’s avatar image from Gravatar.com, and it is assigned to the avatar variable. The model_dump() method of UserModel returns a dictionary containing all the fields that are required for creating an instance of User (except for id). This dictionary is unpacked into keyword arguments for creating new_user using Python’s ** operator.

Parameters:

  • body – UserModel: Create a new user

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

A user object

async src.repository.users.get_user_by_email(email: str, db: AsyncSession) → User | None¶

The get_user_by_email function takes in an email address and a database session. It then queries the database for a user with that email address, returning the first result if it exists.

Parameters:

  • email – str: Specify the type of the email parameter

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

A user object if the user exists in the database

async src.repository.users.update_avatar(email, url: str, db: AsyncSession) → User | None¶

The update_avatar function takes an email and a url as arguments. It then uses the get_user_by_email function to retrieve the user from the database. The avatar property of that user is set to be equal to the url argument, and then the database is committed with those changes.

Parameters:

  • email – Get the user from the database

  • url – str: Pass the url of the avatar image to be updated

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

A user object

async src.repository.users.update_token(user: User, refresh_token: str | None, db: AsyncSession) → None¶

The update_token function updates the refresh token for a user.

Parameters:

  • user – User: Pass the user object to the function

  • refresh_token – str: Update the refresh token in the database

  • db – AsyncSession: Access the database

Returns:

The updated user

REST API routes Addressbook¶

async src.routes.addressbook.add_email_to_contact(contact_id: int, email_create: EmailCreate, db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶
The add_email_to_contact function adds an email to a contact.
The function takes the following parameters:

  • contact_id: int, the id of the contact to add an email address to.

  • email_create: EmailCreate, a JSON object containing information about

    what kind of phone number is being added and its value.

Parameters:

  • contact_id – int: Specify the contact to which we want to add an email

  • email_create – EmailCreate: Create a new email object

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass the database session to the function

  • current_user – User: Get the current user’s id

Returns:

The contact with the added email

async src.routes.addressbook.add_phone_to_contact(contact_id: int, phone_create: PhoneCreate, db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶

The add_phone_to_contact function adds a phone to an existing contact.

The function takes the following arguments:

  • contact_id: int: The id of the contact to add a phone number to.

  • phone_create: PhoneCreate: An object containing information about

    what kind of phone number is being added and its value.

Parameters:

  • contact_id – int: Identify the contact to which we want to add a phone number

  • phone_create – PhoneCreate: Create a new phone object

  • db – AsyncSession: Access the database

  • current_user – User: Get the current user

Returns:

The contact with the added phone

async src.routes.addressbook.create_contact(email_create: EmailCreate, phone_create: PhoneCreate, contact_create: AddressbookCreate, db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶
The create_contact function creates a new contact in the addressbook.

The function takes an AddressbookCreate object, which contains all of the information needed to create a new contact. It also takes an EmailCreate and PhoneCreate objects, which contain all of the information needed to create email and phone numbers for that contact respectively.

Parameters:

  • email_create – EmailCreate: Create a new email object

  • phone_create – PhoneCreate: Create a new phone number for the contact

  • contact_create – AddressbookCreate: Create a contact

  • db – AsyncSession: Get the database session

  • current_user – User: Get the user who is logged in

Returns:

The contact

async src.routes.addressbook.read_contact(contact_id: int, db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user)) → AddressBookContact¶

The read_contact function returns a contact by its id.

Parameters:

  • contact_id – int: Get the contact id from the url

  • db – AsyncSession: Get the database session

  • current_user – User: Get the user who is currently logged in

Returns:

A contact object

async src.routes.addressbook.read_contact_days_to_birthday(days_to_birthday: int = Path(PydanticUndefined), db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶

The read_contact_days_to_birthday function returns a list of contacts that have their birthday in the next 7 days.

Parameters:

  • days_to_birthday – int: Filter the contacts by days to birthday

  • le – Limit the number of days to birthday

  • db – AsyncSession: Access the database

  • current_user – User: Get the current user from the database

Returns:

A list of contacts whose birthday is in the next 7 days

async src.routes.addressbook.read_contacts(skip: int = 0, limit: int = 10, db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶

The read_contacts function returns a list of contacts from the addressbook.

Parameters:

  • skip – int: Skip the first n records

  • limit – int: Limit the number of contacts returned

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass the database session to the function

  • current_user – User: Get the user id

Returns:

A list of contacts from the addressbook

async src.routes.addressbook.remove_contact(contact_id: int, db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶

The remove_contact function removes a contact from the addressbook.

Parameters:

  • contact_id – int: Get the contact id from the url

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass a database session to the function

  • current_user – User: Get the current user

Returns:

The deleted contact

async src.routes.addressbook.search_by_criteria(criteria: str, db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶
The search_by_criteria function searches for contacts in the addressbook by a given criteria.

The search is performed on the first name, last name and email fields of each contact. If no matches are found, an empty list is returned.

Parameters:

  • criteria – str: Search the database for a specific contact

  • db – AsyncSession: Get the database session

  • current_user – User: Get the current user from the database

Returns:

A list of contacts

async src.routes.addressbook.update_contact_birthday(contact_id: int, body: AddressbookUpdateBirthday, db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶
The update_contact_birthday function updates the birthday of a contact.

The function takes in an id and a body, which is used to update the birthday of the contact. If no contact with that id exists, then it returns 404 not found.

Parameters:

  • contact_id – int: Get the contact id from the url

  • body – AddressbookUpdateBirthday: Get the new birthday from the request body

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass the database session to the function

  • current_user – User: Get the current user

Returns:

The updated contact

async src.routes.addressbook.update_contact_name(contact_id: int, body: AddressbookUpdateName, db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶

The update_contact_name function updates the name of a contact in the address book.

Parameters:

  • contact_id – int: Find the contact to update

  • body – AddressbookUpdateName: Pass the data to be updated in the contact

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass the database session to the function

  • current_user – User: Get the current user from the database

Returns:

The updated contact

REST API routes Users¶

async src.routes.users.read_users_me(current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user)) → User¶

The read_users_me function is a GET endpoint that returns the current user’s information.

Parameters:

current_user – User: Get the current user from the database

Returns:

The current user object

async src.routes.users.update_avatar_user(file: UploadFile = File(PydanticUndefined), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user), db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db)) → User¶

The update_avatar_user function takes in a file, current_user and db as parameters. The function then uploads the file to cloudinary using the username of the user as its public id. It then builds a url for that image with specific dimensions and crops it to fill those dimensions. Finally, it updates the avatar field in our database with this new url.

Parameters:

  • file – UploadFile: Upload the file to cloudinary

  • current_user – User: Get the current user’s email

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A user object with the new avatar url

REST API routes Auth¶

async src.routes.auth.confirmed_email(token: str, db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db)) → dict¶

The confirmed_email function takes a token and db as parameters. It returns a dict with the message &quot;Email confirmed&quot; if the email is already confirmed, or it will return a dict with the message &quot;Your email is already confirmed&quot; if it isn’t.

Parameters:

  • token – str: Get the email from the token

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

A message if the email is already confirmed or a new one if it has not yet been confirmed

async src.routes.auth.forgot_password(body: RequestEmail, background_tasks: BackgroundTasks, request: Request, db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db)) → dict¶

The forgot_password function is used to send an email to the user with a link that will allow them to reset their password. The function takes in a RequestEmail object, which contains the user’s email address. The function then checks if there is a user associated with that email address and sends an email containing a link for resetting their password.

Parameters:

  • body – RequestEmail: Get the email from the request body

  • background_tasks – BackgroundTasks: Add a task to the background tasks queue

  • request – Request: Get the base url of the application

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass in the database session

Returns:

A message to the user

async src.routes.auth.login(body: OAuth2PasswordRequestForm = Depends(OAuth2PasswordRequestForm), db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db)) → dict¶

The login function is used to authenticate a user.

Parameters:

  • body – OAuth2PasswordRequestForm: Validate the request body

  • db – AsyncSession: Get the database connection

Returns:

A dict with the access_token, refresh_token and token_type

async src.routes.auth.refresh_token(credentials: HTTPAuthorizationCredentials = Security(HTTPBearer), db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db)) → dict¶

The refresh_token function is used to refresh the access token. It takes in a refresh token and returns an access token, a new refresh token, and the type of bearer authorization.

Parameters:

  • credentials – HTTPAuthorizationCredentials: Get the token from the request header

  • db – AsyncSession: Get the database session

Returns:

A dict with the access_token, refresh_token and token type

async src.routes.auth.request_email(body: RequestEmail, background_tasks: BackgroundTasks, request: Request, db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db)) → dict¶

The request_email function is used to send an email to the user with a link that they can click on to confirm their email address. The function takes in a RequestEmail object, which contains the email of the user who wants to confirm their account. It then checks if there is already an account with that email address and whether or not it has been confirmed yet. If there isn’t already an account, or if it has been confirmed, then we return a message saying so; otherwise we send them an email with a link.

Parameters:

  • body – RequestEmail: Get the email from the request body

  • background_tasks – BackgroundTasks: Add the send_email task to the background tasks queue

  • request – Request: Get the base_url of the application

  • db – AsyncSession: Create a database session

Returns:

A message to the user

async src.routes.auth.reset_password(new_password: str, token: str, db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db)) → dict¶

The reset_password function takes in a new password and token, then returns a dict with the user’s information and a detail message. The function first gets the email from the token using auth_service.get_email_from_token(). Then it gets that user from repository users using get_user by email. If there is no such user, an HTTPException is raised with the status code 400 (bad request) and detail “Verification error”. Otherwise, we hash the new password using auth service get password hash(), then change that user’s password to this hashed version of their new one in repository users’

Parameters:

  • new_password – str: Get the new password from the request body

  • token – str: Get the email from the token

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass the database connection to the function

Returns:

A dict with the user and a detail message

async src.routes.auth.signup(body: UserModel, background_tasks: BackgroundTasks, request: Request, db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db)) → dict¶
The signup function creates a new user in the database.

It takes a UserModel object as input, which contains the username and email of the new user. The function then checks if an account with that email already exists, and if it does not, creates a new account using create_user from repository_users.py.

Parameters:

  • body – UserModel: Validate the request body

  • background_tasks – BackgroundTasks: Add a task to the background queue

  • request – Request: Get the base_url of the server

  • db – AsyncSession: Get the database connection

Returns:

A dict with the user and a detail message

REST API service Auth¶

class src.services.auth.Auth¶

Bases: object

ALGORITHM = 'HS256'¶
SECRET_KEY = '7bbb3508e2e129ae2a3eabafdc76f20dd3211ee5660409019f710e2ea3d99f7b'¶
async create_access_token(data: dict, expires_delta: float | None = None) → str¶

The create_access_token function creates a new access token.

Parameters:

  • self – Refer to the current instance of a class

  • data – dict: Pass the data that will be encoded into the jwt

  • expires_delta – Optional[float]: Set the expiration time of the access token

Returns:

An encoded access token

create_email_token(data: dict) → str¶

The create_email_token function creates a token that is used to verify the user’s email address. The function takes in a dictionary of data, and returns an encoded string.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of a class

  • data – dict: Pass in the data that will be encoded into the token

Returns:

A token that is used to verify the user’s email address

async create_refresh_token(data: dict, expires_delta: float | None = None) → str¶
The create_refresh_token function creates a refresh token for the user.

The function takes in two parameters: data and expires_delta. Data is a dictionary containing the user’s id, username, email address, and password hash. Expires_delta is an optional parameter that sets how long the refresh token will be valid for.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • data – dict: Pass the data that will be encoded in the jwt

  • expires_delta – Optional[float]: Set the time until the refresh token expires

Returns:

An encoded refresh token

async decode_refresh_token(refresh_token: str) → str¶
The decode_refresh_token function is used to decode the refresh token.

The function takes in a refresh_token as an argument and returns the email of the user if successful. If unsuccessful, it raises an HTTPException with status code 401 (Unauthorized) and detail ‘Invalid scope for token’ or ‘Could not validate credentials’.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of a class

  • refresh_token – str: Pass the refresh token to the function

Returns:

The email address of the user

async get_current_user(token: str = Depends(OAuth2PasswordBearer), db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db)) → User | None¶

The get_current_user function is a dependency that can be used to get the current user. It will check if the token is valid and return an object of type User or None.

Parameters:

  • self – Access the class attributes

  • token – str: Get the token from the authorization header

  • db – AsyncSession: Get the database session

Returns:

The user object if the token is valid

get_email_from_token(token: str) → str¶

The get_email_from_token function takes a token as an argument and returns the email address associated with that token. The function first tries to decode the token using jwt.decode, which raises a JWTError if it fails to decode the token. If this happens, we raise an HTTPException with status code 422 (Unprocessable Entity) and detail “Invalid Token for Email Verification”. Otherwise, we return the email address from payload[“sub”].

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • token – str: Pass in the token that was sent to the user’s email address

Returns:

The email from the token

get_password_hash(password: str) → str¶

The get_password_hash function takes a password and returns the hashed version of it. The hashing algorithm is defined in the config file, which is passed to CryptContext.

Parameters:

  • self – Refer to the current instance of a class

  • password – str: Pass in the password that we want to hash

Returns:

A hash of the password

oauth2_scheme = <fastapi.security.oauth2.OAuth2PasswordBearer object>¶
pwd_context = <CryptContext>¶
r = Redis<ConnectionPool<Connection<host=localhost,port=6379,db=0>>>¶
verify_password(plain_password, hashed_password) → bool¶

The verify_password function takes a plain-text password and hashed password as arguments. It then uses the CryptContext instance to verify that the plain-text password matches the hashed password.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • plain_password – Get the password that was entered by the user

  • hashed_password – Store the hashed password in the database

Returns:

True if the plain_password is equal to the hashed_password

REST API service Email¶

async src.services.email.send_email(email: EmailStr, username: str, host: str, subject: str, template: str)¶
The send_email function sends an email to the user with a link to verify their account.
The function takes in four arguments:

  1. email - the user’s email address, which is used as both the recipient and sender of this message.

  2. username - the username that was chosen by this user when they signed up for an account. This will be displayed in

    a greeting at the top of their verification page, so it should be personalized for each individual user.

  3. host - The domain name where our website is hosted (e.g., &quot;localhost&quot; or &quot;127.0.

Parameters:

  • email – EmailStr: Specify the email address of the recipient

  • username – str: Pass the username to the template

  • host – str: Create the link for the user to verify their email address

  • subject – str: Set the subject of the email

  • template – str: Specify the template to use for sending the email

Returns:

A coroutine that is not awaited
